document.text: More people visited the historic McLean House at the National Park here Sunday than on any one day since the house where Lee and Grant made peace was dedicated three years ago. The mechanical counter at the McLean House last Sunday registered 545 visitors. And 370 visitors were counted at the Park Service Museum. Feature attraction for those visit ing the Museum during the past week has been a splendid scale model of the entire Old Court House village as it appeared in 1865. This master piece in mineature has just been re stored and mounted on a special table in the middle room of the Museum. It was acquired by the National Park Service in 1947 and been thourghly checked for accuracy and has been refurbished in every detail. It was the original work of Joseph Burns, who died in Washington January 10, 1895. He was either at the Surrender in 1865 or visited Appomattox very shortly thereafter. He made succeeding visits for sketches on the village and carried on an extended correspondence with the late George T. Peers, clerk of the court here in 1865. It is believed that Burns replica is the most auth entic record of the detailed appear ance of Old Appomattox Court House in existance. Made up of 52 buildings, the scale mode was constructed of pins, matches, oiled paper, cigar box boards and various typos of cloth. It was refurbished by . A. Van Lan- deghem, of Wards Road, Lynchburg.

document.text: D eath of an E stim able L ady. Just as our paper went to press last Thursday we received the sad news of the death of one of our best and most honored ladies, Mrs. Geo. T. Peers, whose husband is clerk of our County and Circuit courts. She died last Thursday morning in Lynch burg, at the residence of her brother, Mr. Obas. H. Sackett. Mrs. Peers had been in ill health for some time. This summer she spent a portion of the heated srason at Bine Ridge Springs, hoping tq  receive some benefit. She went to Lynch- bnrg some six or seven weeks ago, where she was placed under the case of a physician, but her con dition grew worse, until for more than a week before her death, her relatives and friends had given up all hopes of her recovery. She was fifty-nine yews of age and had lived in this copnty since a few years after her marriage, where her friends may be numbered by the hundreds. Mrs. Peers was so well and favorably known and her friends were so fond and close to her, iu love and affection, that her death has been felt in almost every home in our county. document.text: Appomattox, April 8 Martha Mildred Stevens Craig, better known as  Aunt Millie and very spry for her 89 years, delights in telling her story of the surrender which took place here April 9, 1865, just 77 years ago Thursday. Aunt Millie, quaint, timid, and full of in terest in her white and negro friends, was active for her age until last spring when she was struck by a bolt of lightening while in bed. She now walks with the aid of a cane, keeps house for her only son, Uncle Bob Craig, who has served as janitor at Appomattox High School for several gen erations. Aunt Millie was 13 at the time of the surrender and was the nurse maid of Charlie Sackett Peers, six month old son of Mr. and Mrs. George T. Peers. Mr. Peers was at that time clerk of the Court of Appomattox andtwas living near the scene of the sur render.  I was walking de floor, patting my baby to sleep, when those yankee soldiers came bustin in Marse Georges house. The soldiers hollered for everybody to leave de house cause the worst battle ever fought was start ing right den. Marse George fetched Miss Jennie by de hand and rushed her off to the hay loft in the stable. Atwood, and re cently found by her daughter, Miss Lynolee Atwood, of Richmond, re veals valuable historical information on the establishment of the Memor ial Cemetery at Old Appomattox, and shows that it was the work of an organization here which was the local forerunner of the chapter of the United Daughters of the Con federacy. Mrs. Calvin Robinson, president of the U. D. C., today released con tents of this aged notebook, supplied her through the cooperation of H. A. Gurney, Custodian here for the National Park Service. It appears that on Friday, May 18, 1866, the ladies of Old Appo mattox Court House and vicinity met in the court room to form a Ladies Association similar to the Ladies Memorial Association in oth er parts of the South. The object was to provide suitable interment for the Confederate Soldiers and to preserve the final resting place as a memorial. Temporary officers were Presi dent, Mrs. E, W. Major Flood donated timber for a fence. Capt. Wm. H. Trent and Maj. Flood arranged to haul the timber. Mr. Francis Meeks cleared the ground for the Memorial Cemetery. An early feature of the Ladies Organization was a series of memor ial addresses. Col, Farrar made the entertained by Maj. Wilmer Mc Lean. A Tableau was presented as a means of raising funds. A Cavalry Company was formed under the command of Capt. Joel W. Flood, becoming Co. H of the 2nd Va. Cavalry. A Company of Heavy Artillery was formed under Capt. James Robertson. A Company of Infantry under Capt. Thos. P. Mat thews, and another Company was formed under Capt. Wm. H. Abbitt, and quite a number of Appomattox citizens living near the rim of the county joined companies from adjoining coun ties. With hearts aflame and bodies dedicated to the Cause they held dear, they went to the front and shared the destiny of the heroes in Gray. Weakened by casualties, new calls came for volunteers, and long after the war, there was a scarcity of able bodied men in the County. Then came April 9, 1865, and the hand of destiny wrote finis across the scroll of four mighty years of struggle Destiny selected Appomattox for one of the major events oi history. Today there is hardly a town- or village in America, that has not heard of Appomattox. Thus ended in this Coun ty, one of the greatest Civil Wars ever chronicled in the files of Time, and at Appomattox began a new page in the history of America. Military rule was established shortly after April 9, 1865. Al county officers were replaced by military appointees. These were men who were selected upon the recommendation of the incumbents, and were willing to take the Iron Clad Oath. In the fall of 1866, an election was held under the Under wood Constitution, which put into effect the 13th and 14th Amendments to the Constitution of the United States, and a new slate of officers were named. Geo. T. Peers became Clerk Wm. T. Johnson Sheriff W. J. Collins, Commissioner of the Revenue the Office of County Treasurer was created Supervisors were provided for, and the ounty Government, practically as we have it now was estab lished. The ravages of four years of war were apparent, and Ap pomattox along with her sister counties, began to repair the wounds. The following years called forth the character and ability of her people, and the present institutions of our Coun- -y are but a tribute to their untiring labor and foresight.
